column1: #Text=If you had something to tell something to your younger self , what would you tell ?

#Text=Because there 's a lot of years where , you know , you are not making money and you are working real hard and you do n't think you are ever gonna get there , but just keep at it , and you will get there .
#Text=All these years , since the technology has taken over , how has the comic book industry changed in your opinion ?
#Text=Well , when I first started ; it has got much easier , and it has gotten more global .

#Text=Like I could work with someone in India and it would n't matter because with Wi-Fi and with e-mail and instant message , you know , the old days , you had to FedEx pages , and you had to scan them , and it would take literally twenty minutes to save a giant file on Photoshop and then you would have to upload film and then you would have to drive the film to FedEx .
#Text=Like I work with people all around the world now , and before , you almost had to kind of work with the Americans and now its really easy to be global .
#Text=Well , as an editor , I read scripts .
#Text=Again and again and again and you read bad scripts and you read good scripts and you learn from everything .
#Text=Like even a bad script can teach you what not to do .
#Text=So I studied all the scripts I read and learned from that .
#Text=You , sometimes you write a bad script and then you figure out what you did wrong , you do better next time .
#Text=If you had a chance to become a superhero , which one would you choose ?
#Text=What would you recommend to the new people getting into comic writing and drawing ?
#Text=My advice is figure out what you want to do and then focus on that because some people try to do everything and they do n't do it well because they are trying to do everything .
#Text=So figure out really what you want to do and just fine-tune that .
